page.title: 05GURNEY SLADE QUARRY
page.content: With the increase in road building from the begining of the 20th.century there was an increase in the demand for roadstone and three quarries opened in Gurney Slade to help meet it. Stone used to be transported from Binegar Station, but the quarries eventually closed, as did the railway. Now there is only one quarry remaining in operation in the village. Once known as Francis Flowers Lime Works, it was originally used to provide stone for lime-burning. The remains of the old lime kilns can still be seen among the new quarry buildings by the roadside. However in 1962 it was bought by Mr. Perry of Morrris and Perry and since then has been quarried for road stone and cement products which are crushed on site. At present some 50 acres are actively used for the extraction of stone.
